title: Will "Captain America: Civil War" gross more in its opening weekend in the US than "Batman vs. Superman: Dawn of Justice" did?
preds: Batman vs Superman is an awful movie....practically anything will beat it.
The statistics does not say so...

Variety reports as follows: 'Marvel-Disney’s “Captain America: Civil War” has opened the summer spectacularly with a dominant $181.8 million weekend at 4,266 U.S. locations.  The third “Captain America” movie met lofty expectations with the fifth-best domestic opening weekend of all time — trailing only  “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” at $248 million, “Jurassic World” at $208.8 million, “Marvel’s The Avengers” at $207.4 million and “Avengers: Age of Ultron” at $191.3 million. It took over the fifth slot from  “Iron Man 3,” which has $174.1 million.'

After seeing first results from friday and saturday, I have to change the forecast direction 180°. Everzwhere are projections for 180mil $, some brave one mentioning even 200mil $. It seems like 166mil $ is a target, that can be achieved after seeing initial results.
dropping bellow consensus, I see far less hype than I expected

BvS:DoJ made $166M in the opening weekend in the US.
CA: CW is looking at an estimated $74.9M opening day, for a $172M-$178.8M total first weekend in the US.
With the open it had on Friday, it would take a 1% occurrence to stop this.
Base on Friday numbers,  I increased my prediction to 99%.
Fandango report on advance ticket sales is persuasive.

http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=4182&p=.htm The most relevant bit: "...strong reviews and swelling fan anticipation for Civil War (92% on RottenTomatoes as of press time) should go a long way to helping this one out this weekend. Additionally, Fandango is reporting Civil War has generated record-breaking advance ticket sales, ranking as the online ticket retailer's #1 pre-selling superhero movie of all time, surpassing Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice, Avengers: Age of Ultron and The Avengers." And: "...Civil War will play at 378 IMAX locations (14 more than Ultron), 480 PLF locations (80 more than Ultron) and more than 3,300 locations will show the film in 3D, up from 2,761 for Ultron, which saw 44% of its overall weekend come from 3D showings. Also last year, Jurassic World opened in 4,274 theaters of which 363 were IMAX locations, approximately 400 were PLF locations and the film saw 48% of its overall weekend haul come from the 3,303 theaters that debuted the film in 3D."
Forecast are becoming overwhelming at this point despite my initial doubts.

Marvel has bigger fan base.
There are no other major titles that CA:CW needs to compete against.
Estimates are pointing to $ 200 million +. That's a great margin compared to $ 166 million but not a "sure" margin.
Taking my cues from ryangarcia's outstanding analysis.
Going down again, I just don't see data that will underline, that this Captain America movie will make twice as much as former movies

Perhaps people are generally fatigued about Arts and Entertainment, but still interested in Civil War.

I got fooled by the headlines.  Civil War opened to $200m overseas on opening weekend.  Not domestic opening: http://deadline.com/2016/05/captain-america-civil-war-jungle-book-huntsman-batman-superman-international-box-office-weekend-results-1201747374/ Now that sounds great, BUT: http://deadline.com/2016/03/batman-v-superman-dawn-of-justice-opening-box-office-results-international-1201725677/ Superman opened to $254m weekend overseas.  So Civil War opened to 20% less than BvS overseas.  This is still going to be closer than you might think domestically.

The reviews have been outstanding 
Marvel brand is very well established
Movie seems to have multiple story lines and large interest
Usually the marvel  movies have a bit more humor which might have winder audience appeal

assumed a probability distribution centered around $181 million; this value was based on a comparison of international opening weekend sales for avengers: age of ultron with civil war's recent international unveiling; the variance of the distribution is set to reflect both an increasing trend for opening weekend sales for captain America movies and the slight decrease experienced from avengers 1 to avengers 2;

First, remove all consideration of movie reviews.  Early reviews for Civil War seem positive, but Winter Soldier still sits at 89% on Rotten Tomatoes and was a bit north of 90% when it opened to only $95M.  Reviews will impact word of mouth and the legs of the movie, but probably have little impact on opening weekend where fans have already decided they will see the movie or avoid the crowds the first few days. Marvel has established itself as a powerful brand in the movie market (the Marvel Cinematic Universe or MCU).  So there's a lot of comparables at http://www.boxofficemojo.com/franchises/chart/?id=avengers.htm Factors in favor of Civil War opening > $166M:
* More characters generally = more money.  Avengers opened to $207 (highest in MCU), Avengers 2 opened to $191 (2nd highest), and even Guardians of the Galaxy opened to $94M (7th highest but impressive given the August release and low name recognition of the characters prior to the film).
* The MCU is the house that Tony Stark (or Robert Downey Jr) built.  The five highest opening MCU films are the five with Tony Stark/RDJ: Avengers 1 & 2 and the three Iron Man films.  While two of those movies opened under $166 they were the first two--Tony Stark's lowest opening weekend in three years is $174. Factors against Civil War opening  > $166M:
* Captain America.  Despite both Captain America films being very positively reviewed, BOTH of the first two Captain America movies combined for opening weekends less than $166 ($65M and $95M).
* Trendlines not in Cap's favor.  Cap's first movie opened at $65M.  HIs second at $95M.  That was a 46% improvement film over film.  Iron Man saw 31% and 36% improvement film over film so that 46% is impressive but with the lower initial opening there was more headroom.  That's still true given Winter Soldier's $95M opening.  But Civil War would need to improve 75% over Winter Soldier's opening to beat BvS--a feat that hasn't been accomplished since The Dark Knight improved on its predecessor by 229%.  Even X-Men: Days of Future Past only managed to beat First Class (also a low opener) by 64%. Many are also comparing Civil War to the Avengers.  The commercials and trailers certainly make a big deal of all the characters (especially Iron Man) and for good reason:
* Avengers opened to $207, Avengers 2 opened to $191.  That was only a drop of 7%, which if Civil War is considered a third Avengers movie and has the same drop then it would exceed $177M.  
* The $177M also assuming a similar drop which might not happen since Avengers 2 reviews were mixed while CIvil War reviews appear to be positive. However, it's entirely possible that movie goers outside the core fan base won't view this as an Avengers movie because of the title and because of Captain America (who is dominant in the advertising but has never had the same huge success as Iron Man).  And while there are many characters in this movie, several of them have been minimally used (Ant-Man, Falcon), at least one is new (Black Panther), and others set to appear haven't even been heavily featured in advertising despite previous appearances (Vision, Scarlet Witch).  One additional reason why movie goers may not consider this an Avengers film is the absence of Thor and Hulk.  Not only was Hulk a recognizable name, but both of those characters created visual moments that made the scale of the Avengers films grander than other MCU movies.  Instead we have a current action shot of a number of normal sized people jumping/running/flying at each other on an airport tarmac. Ultimately, I think the chances of Civil War outgrossing BvS on opening weekend comes down to two scenarios: State 1: Civil War is considered by the public to be Avengers 3.
State 2: Civil War is considered by the public to be another Captain America movie. In State 1, it is highly likely a third Avengers movie could exceed $166M on opening weekend.  The first two movies did so, even despite the second movie's mixed word of mouth.  There is a generally favorable opinion of the MCU and Avengers which would also help its performance.  I would predict there to be a .90 chance that a third Avengers film beats $166M on opening weekend. In State 2, it is highly unlikely that a third Captain America movie exceeds $166M on opening weekend.  Only one superhero movie has been able to improve that much for a sequel (Dark Knight) and Civil War does not have the same core reasons for Dark Knight's success (media sensation of Heath Ledger's performance and low previous film opening).  Although the marketing efforts around Civil War want to equate the movie to Avengers, I think that ultimately falls short and is further indication that Marvel doesn't trust the opening power of Captain America alone.  I would predict there to be a 0.15 chance that a third Captain America film exceeds $166M. Now we have to look at the odds that the consuming public views the movie in either state.  The marketing is pushing towards State 1 but the success of the MCU, and particularly its increasing use of multiple characters within a film, are likely to make State 2 more likely.  I would predict that movie goers are 0.75 likely to view this as a Captain America movie. Chances that Civil War outgrosses BvS would therefore be: .90 State 1 success * .25 chance of State 1 + .15 State 2 success * .75 chance of State 2 = .3375 or 34%. UPDATE: The opening foreign numbers are starting to come in and international movie-goers are showing a much stronger preference for this to be treated like an Avengers movie rather than a Captain America movie.  That's a surprise given their failure to do so with Cap 2 but it had for fewer additional characters.  So I am updating the percentage change of State 1 to be .90 given the huge difference between Cap 3 and Cap 2 opening weekends in foreign markets. Additionally, if you compare the foreign openings of Cap 3 to Ultron you do see a slight decline (just as we saw a drop for Avengers 1 and 2).  These are difficult to compare as some have slight drops (Australia had $12.3M for Ultron, $10.6 for Cap 3), some are large increases (South Korea had $23M for Ultron, $29M for Cap 3), and some are large drops (UK had $27.3M for Ultron, $20.5 for Cap 3).  But given that a large drop would need to be consistent for a third Avengers movie, I am increasing the percentage of State 1 succeeding to .98.  So the new numbers look like: .98 State 1 success * .90 chance of State 1 + .15 State 2 success * .10 chance of State 2 = .897 or 90%

This is my first ever forecast and i have to say it is proving more troublesome than I imagined. I am not a huge movie buff, and certainly wouldn't watch this genre, which should help me to make a well informed 'emotionless' forecast - but that hasn't been the case. I think this could be a close run race and don't know whether this movie:
- has more/less appeal than BvS?
- if the bank holiday release of BvS had any effect? (boosting sales)
- if this movie (Captain America) will ride the current superhero wave or indicate superhero fatigue? For me, as a complete novice on this subject, I would suggest that BvS had more appeal and therefore a bigger fanbase. However, RDJ does add some star-appeal to the Captain America movie, which I am guessing will have mass appeal in the US (Captain America must be every American boys first choice superhero - right?) I think it will be a close call but I think BvS may just edge it. .... Anyhow, lets see how my first forecast goes. At worst I will be able to reflect on my mistakes!

Excellent reviews (among the best for a Marvel movie) are amplified by opening outside the US weeks before the US opening so momentum of word-of-mouth can build. The last team-up Marvel movie (or comparable movie) was Avengers/Ultron (75% RT, 191M domestic opening) and Civil War is already at 97% RT with a decent sample of reviews, suggesting this should open over $200M. There's still a chance of some extenuating circumstances that affect the broad number of people that will go to the theater, but everything appears to have lined up for a huge, possibly record-setting weekend in 13 days.

I think question formulation anchores to find answers, why the movie should make more than 166mil. After inversing the statement - will Captain America make at most 166mil, lot of forecasts would assign about 1-5% probability which is I think, too low.  Reason I don't think movie will make more than 166mil:
1.) It will need to raise first week gains by roughly 75%, which never happend before considering Marvel movies
2.) With series - % income increase rate tends to drop in most cases with adding new titles to existing series Reason why it can make more:
1.) First Captain America was made by Paramount, scond and third are made by Buena Vista. Even when Avengers specifically wasn't the case, the increased opening week incomes for other Marvel movies (Iron Man, Thor) for which they got license after original producer.
2.) The budget - opening week incomes relationship is very strong for Buena Vista. Strongest among all Marvel movie producers. Summary:
In total almost doubling opening week incomes is really challenging. Adding 1mil. to the budget can, based on former studies, add anywhere between 0.58$-1.33$ mil to final opening week outcome. In this case, that means to gain additional 70,983,626$ they would need to spent additional 53.4-122.3mil to previous budget. That would meen 220mil-292mil. It would help to know the movie budget, but in this light - Captain America needs to be the new Avengers. 
There is a change it will happen, but it would be first case of it's kind.

Avengers and Avengers: Age of Ultron hold the first and second place spots with $207 million and $187 million respectively ..."  but they're both crappy movies.

Can you read the future? I can but, only when it pertains to the new Captain America franchise "Civil War" i'm afraid. Besides the fact that Batman v Superman was a tired pony from the start of the race as far as movie drum-up i.e., a lame opening weekend ticket gross domestically in the United States, Marvel just has bigger plans than the boys across the aisle. Marvel's film will exceed DC's opening weekend gross and it's thanks to the lads in the writer's room. This film has a very mediated tone potentially leading in many directions. Bucky Barnes, who is being pursued for his brain-washed actions in Captain America: Winter Soldier, takes on a number of Avengers, including Iron Man and Black Widow. This is a turning-point scene, as Bucky unloads a bullet from point-blank range at Tony Stark (Iron Man). This is a clear warning to the playboy genius that it's now a blood sport and there is no turning back. This scene is revealing a very provocative storyline future to come and if the whole film is on this level it will exceed well over $166,007,347 domestic which was the total gross for Batman v Superman in it's opening weekend. Furthermore, the DC Comic film's domestic gross was only 37.5% of its total lifetime gross. I cannot wait to see what this sequence throws into motion. One year after the events of Avengers: Age of Ultron, another incident occurs involving the Avengers resulting in collateral damage, enticing politicians to voice the need for closer management of such beings. And form a system of accountability and a governing body to determine when the Avengers are needed. When Steve Rogers (Captain America) attempts to protect Barnes and ends up in a conflict with Stark. The Avengers divide into two opposing leagues—one led by Captain America, who wishes to operate without convoluting regulation, and the other by Iron Man, who can sees value in government sovereignty over the team. 

    This film becomes quite poetic once you begin to sense the euphemism for modern American political differences beneath the storyline's suggestive current. Captain America portraying the conservative struggle for a free and wholesome life and Iron Man resembling the liberal willingness to submit to government protection and equal benefit for all. This theme seems to paint the walls and canvases of Marvel's "Civil War" empire. Marvel stands to make a king's ransom from this picture domestically and abroad, a film of controversy and depth.
Previousl;y I thought this was a low chance but after viewing Batman I realised this was a real possibility as I would expect the movie will be superior and the hype is considerable

Superman has largely lost the gravity it once held over the American psyche. He's a boring character, and as much as Batman counterbalances Superman's boring composition, American audiences have probably seen a bit too much of him over the past few years to get excited about such a title.
People are bored and will watch anything.

Comic book fan that I am, I must confess a strong Marvel preference. That, combined with a "blah" reaction to the sepia-toned first saga of the Cavill Superman sequence (in darker-still 3D), made the opening weekend haul of "BvS" truly gob-smacking. (I skipped it.) So I am guided in my prediction by my oldest sons, who streamed "Superman" and liked it much better on the second viewing, then contributed to the above-mentioned $166M-- matinee showing, no concessions. They have already offered to take their younger brothers to see "Civil War" on opening weekend. They have not asked me to pay for any of the tickets, nor to provide concessions cash. A late-night showing has been suggested, for "better crowd experience" (translation: younger, louder, more likely to throw popcorn). When a couple of tightwads are willing to shell out prime-time cash, I'd be a fool not to read that as a measure of real, actionable excitement. I'm betting that they're pretty representative of millennial [male] movie-goers in this regard.

The second Captain America movie did substantially better than the first, and I think we'll continue to see improved performance here. However, this isn't merely a Captain America movie -- this is more of an Avengers movie, and those tend to do well opening weekend and beyond. DC has had a couple of big releases in recent years, but hasn't really had that much hype since the Dark Knight trilogy. Even though lots of people saw Batman vs. Superman in theaters, most people came out saying it was awful and they felt robbed.
The movie has been screened and tested better than all initial DOJ, and already has a large fan following.  In addition the promotion for this movie has been well made.

Only three movies in the MCU have ever grossed more that 166 mil, two of which were avengers movies. However, since Civil War is being marketed as an ensemble story (not just captain America is in it) there is potential for it to gross as much as an avengers movie.

The key question is, is Civil War more like the Avengers and Iron Man franchises, which would be highly likely to beat $166M with a new release based on previous results, or more like previous Captain America (or other second tier Marvel franchises, such as Thor or Ant Man) which have generally been $50-100M openings. Because this is an ensemble movie like previous "Avengers" movies, I'm weighting the >$166M scenario as more likely by about 2:1.

Coming down from 99, which is really over-confident (My very first "just for fun" question on GJP3 was an incorrect prediction on whether the "Wolverine" would exceed its target). From what I can make out, Civil War is thought to be better then Batman and Superman, and should out-gross it in the long run, but the opening weekend could easily be impacted by outside factors (could even be the weather).  I'd rather stay a little below consensus while checking out more sources predicting box office returns.
No, because Captain America has been in so many movies and people are getting tired of him.

Previous Captain America movies had opening grosses smaller than $166m.  Avengers movie had bigger opening gross than $166m.  The new movie is really an Avengers movie, but not titled as such, so it depends on how the advertising goes.
Capt  America is awesome also a continuation of a series.

I see more consumer acceptance of the Marvel Comics heroes than I do with the older DC Comics stars. Captain America is a relative newcomer to the cinema, and has only appeared in a handful of films. As such, he is still considered something of a newbie. I also think the Superman and (especially) Batman franchises are over the hill in the eyes of moviegoers, and that these two older stars have less left in them. Therefore, I predict the Captain America film will start stronger and last longer than the Superman vs. Batman film.

First off, GO #TEAMCAP! This will likely do better than Dawn of Justice, but not by much. DoJ did well its opening weekend because no matter how bad the reviewers said it was. Everyone that was ever interested was going to see it no matter what. Also, even though film makers are trying to make each movie stand-alone, you can't get over the idea that this is a sequel. In fact, it's a super-sequel. It's essentially Part 13 of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. So far, this hasn't really been an issue, but it's possible this is the one that makes too many movie goers decide to skip it because they didn't see every single one of the previous movies. One the other hand, even though it has the same rating as DOJ, Marvel has made a more kid-friendly franchise. It's rock-em, sock'em without the accidental mass body count. Plus, Civil War is a Captain America movie guest starring EVERYONE. A lot of non-fanboys/fangirls that liked Iron Man, Ant Man or Avengers will see it for those stars. On top of that,the re-introduction of Spider-Man will help get people into seats.

Looking at the HSX numbers, I think 80% is too high.   At a moment of its high hype (a month before release, not sure its max yet), CA3 is 430 on HSX.  http://www.hsx.com/security/view/CAPA3
At the moment of its maximum hype (a month before its release), Age of Ultron was 588 on HSX.  http://www.hsx.com/security/view/AVNG2
At the moment of its max hype (about a month before its release), Batman v Superman was 460 on HSX.  http://www.hsx.com/security/view/SUPE2 It's hard to calibrate hype into bands, but clearly there's a much higher band of hype CA3 can get to yet.  It's yet to plumb the heights of hype.

Just adding some HSX numbers: http://www.hsx.com/security/view/CAPA3 (429 over 4 weeks)
http://www.hsx.com/security/view/CAPA2 (225 over 4 weeks)
http://www.hsx.com/security/view/AVNG2 (411 over 4 weeks)
http://www.hsx.com/security/view/SUPE2 (ended up 325 over 4 weeks, but it spiked to 460 just at the time of release). Captain America:Civil War is now at Age of Ultron type numbers rather than Captain America 2 numbers.   Also very close to Batman v. Superman numbers, before the rash of bad reviews for that one. But HSX is famous for having movie stocks shoot up in the period just before release.  A month ago, Civil War was at $350 over 4 weeks, about halfway between Captain America 2 and Age of Ultron numbers.   I think it's still likely a yes, but it's easy to get caught up in the hype.  I think a better base rate is still somewhere halfway between Age of Ultron and Cap America 2, about $150 million with it more likely to end up on the high side of that.  Even now at time of close to maximum hype, CA3 is only hitting Age of Ultron numbers on HSX.  If it starts exceeding Age of Ultron numbers on HSX, then I'll move up again.  At the moment of its maximum hype, Age of Ultron was 588 over 4 weeks (about a month before release).

I'm going in a little under forecast. I agree that it is very likely CA CW will win, but I think the consensus is too high here. Some stats on recent marvel movies (Inflation adjusted) -  CA - $69m
CA2 - $96m
Avengers - $215m
Avengers 2 - $192m
Ant Man - $57m
GOTG - $95m
Iron Man - $110m
Iron Man 2 - $140m
Iron Man 3 - $178m
Amazing Spider-man  - $62m
Amazing Spider-man 2 - $93m
Spider Man - $152m
Spider Man 2 - $111m
Spider Man 3 - $173m If Captain America 3 is seen as another Avengers movie, we would expect it to break $160m. HOWEVER, Avengers 2 did actually drop by $23m compared to the first. A similar drop would get us to $169m, so we're in choppy waters. I would not expect this to happen, Avengers 2's fall off was likely due poorer reviews, and CA3 does not seem to be getting this. However, this plus the lack on an actual Avengers title, I suspect, means this will be close. CA2 did $27m better than CA1. Another similar jump takes us to $123m. I think the jump will be higher than that, due to the extra draw of Iron Man, Spider Man etc. $160m+ is, however still a bit jump here. Ant Man and GOTG probably aren't that important comparisons, due to lack of existing characters. I'm not sure why I looked them up, but the numbers are there. RDJ's Iron Man is a big draw. His 3 solo films saw big jumps every time, and since he is featuring prominently on advertising, if we were to treat this as Iron Man 4 I would expect it to beat BVS. Just following the trend gets comfortably into Avenger's territory. The last 3 films featuring the character all beat BVS on opening weekend by a long way. I think this is the best argument in favour of a high %, and this is why I am going in so high. Spider-Man can be a big draw, but he isn't what he once was. The older films were pushing the BVS mark, but the newer ones are a long way down. May is pretty peak film releasing time, but I don't think it has big help over BVS here. There is little to compete with it, but there wasn't for BVS either. Finally, two forecasts I found from people predicting both films opening weekends before BVS came out. I am not sure of their methodology, but they seem to have both been broadly correct on BVS, suggesting some validity. http://pro.boxoffice.com/long-range-forecast-captain-america-civil-war/ This had CA winning very narrowly, but BVS beat its prediction. Possible CA will do that too. http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2016/03/batman_v_superman_and_captain.html This gave a similar figure for BVS, but predicts CA in the $140-$150m range. I think this is low. I suspect consensus is a little high due to overvaluing effects of reviews. BVS was panned, CA3 is doing well in these stakes. However, I'm not sure this makes a huge difference to opening weekends in franchises like this, and is more important later on via word of mouth. I'd be almost 100% confident CA3 will beat BVS in the long term. All in all, I'm reasonably confident that CA will beat BVS on opening weekend, but I think consensus is slightly too high here. If I were predicting blind, I would have maybe gone lower, and said maybe a 60-70% chance, but I don't want to gamble that much of my brier score on a topic I'm a bit ignorant of, so I'm going in comfortable below consensus, but hedging due to you all being so certain.

First, remove all consideration of movie reviews.  Early reviews for Civil War seem positive, but Winter Soldier still sits at 89% on Rotten Tomatoes and was a bit north of 90% when it opened to only $95M.  Reviews will impact word of mouth and the legs of the movie, but probably have little impact on opening weekend where fans have already decided they will see the movie or avoid the crowds the first few days. Marvel has established itself as a powerful brand in the movie market (the Marvel Cinematic Universe or MCU).  So there's a lot of comparables at http://www.boxofficemojo.com/franchises/chart/?id=avengers.htm Factors in favor of Civil War opening > $166M:
* More characters generally = more money.  Avengers opened to $207 (highest in MCU), Avengers 2 opened to $191 (2nd highest), and even Guardians of the Galaxy opened to $94M (7th highest but impressive given the August release and low name recognition of the characters prior to the film).
* The MCU is the house that Tony Stark (or Robert Downey Jr) built.  The five highest opening MCU films are the five with Tony Stark/RDJ: Avengers 1 & 2 and the three Iron Man films.  While two of those movies opened under $166 they were the first two--Tony Stark's lowest opening weekend in three years is $174. Factors against Civil War opening  > $166M:
* Captain America.  Despite both Captain America films being very positively reviewed, BOTH of the first two Captain America movies combined for opening weekends less than $166 ($65M and $95M).
* Trendlines not in Cap's favor.  Cap's first movie opened at $65M.  HIs second at $95M.  That was a 46% improvement film over film.  Iron Man saw 31% and 36% improvement film over film so that 46% is impressive but with the lower initial opening there was more headroom.  That's still true given Winter Soldier's $95M opening.  But Civil War would need to improve 75% over Winter Soldier's opening to beat BvS--a feat that hasn't been accomplished since The Dark Knight improved on its predecessor by 229%.  Even X-Men: Days of Future Past only managed to beat First Class (also a low opener) by 64%. Many are also comparing Civil War to the Avengers.  The commercials and trailers certainly make a big deal of all the characters (especially Iron Man) and for good reason:
* Avengers opened to $207, Avengers 2 opened to $191.  That was only a drop of 7%, which if Civil War is considered a third Avengers movie and has the same drop then it would exceed $177M.  
* The $177M also assuming a similar drop which might not happen since Avengers 2 reviews were mixed while CIvil War reviews appear to be positive. However, it's entirely possible that movie goers outside the core fan base won't view this as an Avengers movie because of the title and because of Captain America (who is dominant in the advertising but has never had the same huge success as Iron Man).  And while there are many characters in this movie, several of them have been minimally used (Ant-Man, Falcon), at least one is new (Black Panther), and others set to appear haven't even been heavily featured in advertising despite previous appearances (Vision, Scarlet Witch).  One additional reason why movie goers may not consider this an Avengers film is the absence of Thor and Hulk.  Not only was Hulk a recognizable name, but both of those characters created visual moments that made the scale of the Avengers films grander than other MCU movies.  Instead we have a current action shot of a number of normal sized people jumping/running/flying at each other on an airport tarmac. Ultimately, I think the chances of Civil War outgrossing BvS on opening weekend comes down to two scenarios: State 1: Civil War is considered by the public to be Avengers 3.
State 2: Civil War is considered by the public to be another Captain America movie. In State 1, it is highly likely a third Avengers movie could exceed $166M on opening weekend.  The first two movies did so, even despite the second movie's mixed word of mouth.  There is a generally favorable opinion of the MCU and Avengers which would also help its performance.  I would predict there to be a .90 chance that a third Avengers film beats $166M on opening weekend. In State 2, it is highly unlikely that a third Captain America movie exceeds $166M on opening weekend.  Only one superhero movie has been able to improve that much for a sequel (Dark Knight) and Civil War does not have the same core reasons for Dark Knight's success (media sensation of Heath Ledger's performance and low previous film opening).  Although the marketing efforts around Civil War want to equate the movie to Avengers, I think that ultimately falls short and is further indication that Marvel doesn't trust the opening power of Captain America alone.  I would predict there to be a 0.15 chance that a third Captain America film exceeds $166M. Now we have to look at the odds that the consuming public views the movie in either state.  The marketing is pushing towards State 1 but the success of the MCU, and particularly its increasing use of multiple characters within a film, are likely to make State 2 more likely.  I would predict that movie goers are 0.75 likely to view this as a Captain America movie. Chances that Civil War outgrosses BvS would therefore be: .90 State 1 success * .25 chance of State 1 + .15 State 2 success * .75 chance of State 2 = .3375 or 34%. UPDATE: The opening foreign numbers are starting to come in and international movie-goers are showing a much stronger preference for this to be treated like an Avengers movie rather than a Captain America movie.  That's a surprise given their failure to do so with Cap 2 but it had for fewer additional characters.  So I am updating the percentage change of State 1 to be .90 given the huge difference between Cap 3 and Cap 2 opening weekends in foreign markets. Additionally, if you compare the foreign openings of Cap 3 to Ultron you do see a slight decline (just as we saw a drop for Avengers 1 and 2).  These are difficult to compare as some have slight drops (Australia had $12.3M for Ultron, $10.6 for Cap 3), some are large increases (South Korea had $23M for Ultron, $29M for Cap 3), and some are large drops (UK had $27.3M for Ultron, $20.5 for Cap 3).  But given that a large drop would need to be consistent for a third Avengers movie, I am increasing the percentage of State 1 succeeding to .98.  So the new numbers look like: .98 State 1 success * .90 chance of State 1 + .15 State 2 success * .10 chance of State 2 = .897 or 90%   I have entered another prediction with these numbers but wanted to update here as well.

Both Avengers movies had bigger opening weekends than BvS [1], and CW is most clearly an Avengers movie due to the massive number of characters involved, how it's being advertised, and how much it's being advertised. So the base rate for "Avengers movie beats BvS" is 100%, but with only 2 data points. The base rate for "movie beats BvS" is essentially zero though. The base rate for "Marvel movie beats BvS" is about 10% (20% over last 8 years, since big reboots, feels more relevant). Not sure how to combine these. If you look at inflation-adjusted values, both Iron Man 3 and Spiderman 3 also beat BvS --- and both characters are in CW. (Reasonable to assume characters are main reason people see these?) Also, for the fans, Spiderman being in a movie with other heroes is a huge deal, we have been waiting forever. (I'd drag my face across a mile of broken glass just to hear that movie through a walkie-talkie.) But the fans might be a small number, maybe most people don't see it that way. It is tempting to discount BvS because critics panned it, but critics also panned Spiderman 3 and it's right up there in the biggest openings. Another way that CW might fail to beat BvS is by losing audiences to movies / events happening around the same time. There are no blockbusters coming out within 2 weeks of CW (before or after) [2,3]. On the other hand, NBA semifinals will happen that weekend [4]. Overall I'm pretty confident CW will beat BvS: 85% yes. (The 95% was a typo!) [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_openings_for_films#Biggest_opening_weekends_in_the_U.S._and_Canada
[2] http://movieweb.com/movies/2016/april/
[3] http://movieweb.com/movies/2016/may/
[4] http://www.masslive.com/sports/2016/04/2016_nba_playoffs_full_tv_sche.html

Rotten Tomatoes rating (4/13/16) = 100%
Metacritic rating (4/13/16) = 84......but read the reviews, some are virtually glowing but have a low rating. Example: Sheri Linden of the Hollywood Reported. Seriously Sheri....a 70????.. after writing ......It builds upon the plotlines of previous Avengers outings, bringing together known marquee quantities and introducing the Black Panther and a new Spidey in winning fashion.....As the third Captain America film jump-starts the summer movie season, and something called Phase 3 of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, its box-office muscle is beyond question......But for all their kickass moves and fretting close-ups, such charismatic actors as Cheadle and Johansson feel sidelined through much of the story.....The movie’s center does hold, though, in the well-played contrast between Steve Rogers and Tony Stark. Rogers’ anachronistic aspects are no longer the source of punchlines, and Evans persuasively conveys his decency without overstating the matter. Through their contained performances, he and Sebastian Stan, as Bucky Barnes (aka the Winter Soldier), give emotional heft to their characters’ friendship, a crucial element of the story. Just as crucial, Evans leaves room for doubt about whether Rogers is right to resist outside rules, even as the film clearly sides with him.....Downey, whose ace timing and effortless snark make him the movie’s chief comic relief, also provides pivotal emotional chords.  Is that a 70 rating after all that narrative? Were you drunk or just lazy sending this one in to the the editors? As pointed out, this movie is part of the Summer kickoff...more people getting out, getting together.....one variable driving the box office.  Not sure when I last saw a 100% on Rotten Tomatoes, though admittedly this is with a limited number of critics at this stage....nonetheless....worth noting.

May 6th opening weekend is quiet (http://www.movieinsider.com/movies/may/2016/6) with seemingly no-one prepared to compete vs Marvel, so no competition there. Buena Vista has released three other Marvel movies that weekend previously (2 avenger movies and Iron Man 3), all of which made more than 166m. Also while May is in the top 5 grossing months, it also seems to have the advantage of less releases. So the chosen weekend should allow a take bigger than 166m. Moving onto the movie itself, the Captain America franchise (average 80m), clearly does not have the same opening potential as the Avengers (average 199m), or the novelty factor of BvS, so that would argue against it managing to beat 166m, however and this is definitely not the most scientific of methods, I have three kids and all of them are looking at this as Avengers 3 not Captain America 3. As does seemingly the studio, with budget rumours being much closer if not higher than the two Avenger movies. So with that I was going to start at 90%, however, given BvS has the seventh best opening weekend of all time, I probably need to temper it by another 4%.

While the Avengers movies beat BVS at the box office, I'm unsure if a stand alone Captain America movie will beat that opening weekend. However, the MCU is more established than DC in movies and BVS was released amid many bad reviews.
